channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2018 The New York Times Company

item.title: Kim Jong-un’s China Visit Strengthens His Hand in Nuclear Talks
item.media:description: In images and in words, President Xi Jinping of China and Kim Jong-un, the North Korean leader, signaled on Wednesday that they had repaired the relationship between their countries.
item.description: The North Korean leader’s first diplomatic trip since taking power was a reminder of how much he has set the agenda over his nation’s nuclear arsenal.
item.dc:creator: JANE PERLEZ
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament

item.title: At Least 68 Dead as Fire Erupts Amid Riot at Venezuela Jail
item.media:description: Anguished relatives of inmates outside a police station in Valencia, Venezuela, where a deadly fire broke out during a riot.
item.description: The announcement hours came after crowds of anguished family members had gathered outside the facility, some weeping and others facing off with police officers in riot gear.
item.dc:creator: ANA VANESSA HERRERO

item.title: How Viktor Orban Bends Hungarian Society to His Will
item.media:description: Prime Minister Viktor Orban addressing a crowd at a national celebration in Budapest this month.
item.description: To populists like Stephen Bannon, Hungary’s prime minister, Viktor Orban, is “a hero.” But democracy advocates fear his relentless remolding of society.
item.dc:creator: PATRICK KINGSLEY

item.title: Skopje Journal: Dancing Nymphs and Pirate Ships: Notes from a Capital of Kitsch
item.media:description: This statue in Skopje, Macedonia, of a man with his fist raised could be Philip II, father of Alexander the Great. Or not.
item.media:credit: Akos Stiller for The New York Times
item.description: An ambitious building project that started in Skopje, Macedonia’s capital, in 2008, was meant to evoke an ancient past. It has created a wild present.
item.dc:creator: MARC SANTORA

item.title: France Honors Officer Killed After Taking a Hostage’s Place
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron of France paid his respects at a memorial ceremony for Col. Arnaud Beltrame in Paris on Wednesday.
item.description: Lt. Col. Arnaud Beltrame received a eulogy from President Emmanuel Macron and was accorded a hero’s memorial in Paris for his act of courage.
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Mireille Knoll, Murdered Holocaust Survivor, Is Honored in Paris
item.media:description: A march in memory of Mireille Knoll in Paris on Wednesday. Ms. Knoll, a 85-year-old Holocaust survivor, was found murdered in her apartment last week.
item.description: Thousands marched against anti-Semitic violence. Ms. Knoll, 85, was stabbed and burned in her home.
item.dc:creator: ELIAN PELTIER and AURELIEN BREEDEN

item.title: Poison Was Left on Russian Spy’s Front Door, the British Police Say
item.media:description: Police officers outside the home of Sergei V. Skripal, a former Russian double agent who was poisoned by a nerve agent, in Salisbury, England.
item.description: After the Skripals were found unconscious, investigators looked at many ways they could have been poisoned, like a bouquet or a car ventilation system
item.dc:creator: ELLEN BARRY

item.title: Pope Rejects Call for Apology to Canada’s Indigenous People
item.media:description: Pope Francis, above in Rome this week, will not apologize for the church’s role in a Canadian system that forced generations of Indigenous children into boarding schools.
item.description: Canada’s Catholic bishops said Pope Francis would not apologize for the church’s role in an educational system that tried to eliminate Indigenous culture.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN and JASON HOROWITZ

item.title: They Were ‘Known Only to God.’ Now Argentina’s Falklands War Dead Are Named.
item.media:description: Relatives of an Argentine soldier killed during the 1982 war between Argentina and Britain visited the Darwin Military Cemetery in the Falkland Islands, known by Argentina as Malvinas Islands, for the first time this week.
item.description: Argentina has identified the remains of 90 service members killed in the 1982 war, enabling relatives to visit the labeled graves for the first time.
item.dc:creator: DANIEL POLITI
item.category: International Committee of the Red Cross

item.title: Anbang Was Seized by China. Now, It Has a Deal for You.
item.media:description: Anbang offices in Beijing. In recent years, investors have poured money into wealth management products offered by companies like Anbang that enabled the companies to go on buying binges around the world.
item.description: The troubled company continued selling investments to middle class Chinese despite Beijing’s debt crackdown — and the offers still appeal to many.
item.dc:creator: SUI-LEE WEE and ZHANG TIANTIAN

item.title: Yu Gwan-sun, a Korean Independence Activist Who Defied Japanese Rule
item.media:description: Yu Gwan-sun took an active part in the March 1, 1919, independence movement against Japanese colonial rule in Korea. Dying in prison at 17, she became a national hero.
item.description: When a call for peaceful protests came in spring 1919, a schoolgirl became the face of a nation’s collective yearning for freedom.
item.dc:creator: INYOUNG KANG

item.title: Trade Deals Take Years. Trump Wants to Remake Them in Months.
item.media:description: Shipping containers at the Port of Los Angeles in San Pedro, Calif. To secure trade agreements quickly, the White House has taken a contentious approach to negotiations.
item.description: A series of looming deadlines will put pressure on U.S. partners to reach deals, in a high-risk strategy that may not solve deeper and more persistent problems.
item.dc:creator: KEITH BRADSHER
item.category: Office of the United States Trade Representative

item.title: Ecuador Cuts Off Julian Assange’s Internet Access. Again.
item.media:description: Julian Assange has lived at the Ecuadorean Embassy in London since 2012 to avoid extradition to Sweden.
item.description: The government said it was concerned that Mr. Assange, who lives in the Ecuadorean Embassy in London, was harming the country’s international relationships on social media.
item.dc:creator: SEWELL CHAN

item.title: Kim Jong-un, Michael Flynn, Stephon Clark: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
item.media:credit: KCNA, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: KAREN ZRAICK and DAVID SCULL

item.title: Bulletin Board: ‘He Is Not a Victim’: Our Austin Bomber Coverage Explained
item.media:description: Officials investigating near a vehicle where Mark Conditt, the suspect in the deadly Austin bombings, blew himself up as the authorities closed in on him in Round Rock, Tex., on March 21.
item.media:credit: Jay Janner/Austin American-Statesman, via Associated Press
item.description: Times journalists respond to some of the most common questions we received from readers about our coverage of the Austin bomber.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Letter 51: Getting to Know (and Appreciate) Rural Australia
item.media:description: Pyramid Hill, Victoria.
item.description: This week’s Australia Letter, written and delivered from inside a country pub.
item.dc:creator: DAMIEN CAVE

item.title: American Drone Strike in Libya Kills Top Qaeda Recruiter
item.media:description: The aftermath of an American airstrike in 2016 on an Islamic State militant training camp in rural Libya. Until now, the Pentagon had focused its counterterrorism strikes in Libya almost exclusively on Islamic State fighters and operatives farther north.
item.description: The recruiter, Musa Abu Dawud, provided logistics, money and weapons that enabled the group to threaten and attack U.S. and Western interests, the military said.
item.dc:creator: ERIC SCHMITT
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb

item.title: Quebec City Mosque Gunman Pleads Guilty to Murder
item.media:description: Alexandre Bissonnette, a former university student who killed six men at a mosque in Quebec last year, attended a court session in Quebec City last week.
item.description: Several of the victims’ family members sobbed in court after the judge read out the names of the six men killed in the attack, in which five others were seriously wounded.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY
item.category: Islamic Cultural Center of Quebec City

item.title: Woman Becomes First South African Imprisoned for Racist Speech
item.description: The viral video of Vicki Momberg’s 2016 rant against black police officers has set off a national debate about the limits of free speech.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD PÉREZ-PEÑA

item.title: After Years of Unrest, Ethiopia Seeks Calm With a New Leader
item.media:description: Abiy Ahmed is expected to become Ethiopia’s prime minister.
item.description: Abiy Ahmed will be the first member of the Oromo ethnic group, which makes a up a third of Ethiopia’s population, to lead the government.
item.dc:creator: HADRA AHMED and JINA MOORE

item.title: Deal With U.S. Military Sets Off Protests in Ghana
item.media:description: Protesters in Accra, Ghana, demonstrated Wednesday against a military agreement with the United States.
item.description: An agreement expanding the American military’s relationship with Ghana struck a nerve on a continent where the presence of United States soldiers is receiving more scrutiny.
item.dc:creator: DIONNE SEARCEY and ERIC SCHMITT
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Australian Court to Decide Whether Cardinal Pell Faces Trial
item.media:description: Cardinal George Pell, who has been accused of “historical sexual offenses,” outside the Melbourne Magistrates’ Court last week.
item.description: A decision is expected in April on whether Cardinal George Pell, who is accused of committing sexual offenses decades ago, will be tried.
item.dc:creator: ADAM BAIDAWI

item.title: Your Cute Rubber Duck May Be a Haven for Bacteria
item.media:description: A study that tested 19 different bath toys found that the murky water released by rubber ducks can contain “potentially pathogenic bacteria” that can cause eye, ear and stomach infections.
item.description: A study of bath toys found the water inside yellow ducks swimming with microbes, including bacteria often associated with hospital infections.
item.dc:creator: CEYLAN YEGINSU
item.category: Swiss Federal Institute of Aquatic Science and Technology, ETH Zurich

item.title: Sculpture of Winged Bull Destroyed by ISIS Is Recreated for London’s Fourth Plinth
item.media:description: The American artist Michael Rakowitz’s sculpture, “The Invisible Enemy Should Not Exist,” in London.
item.description: The work by the American artist Michael Rakowitz is the latest project to sit atop the sculpture platform on Trafalgar Square.
item.dc:creator: ANNA CODREA-RADO
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
The Invisible Enemy Should Not Exist

item.title: As Russia Mourns Victims of Mall Fire, Some Chant, ‘Corruption Kills!’
item.media:description: Russia was in an official state of mourning on Wednesday as funerals began for the 64 victims of a fire at a mall in Kemerovo. Many of those killed were children.
item.description: Funerals began for the 64 victims in Kemerovo, many of them children, while outrage mounted over a perceived lack of official accountability.
item.dc:creator: MATTHEW LUXMOORE

item.title: Serial Rapist’s Release Is Blocked, for Now, by U.K. Court
item.media:description: John Worboys, a former London cab driver, was convicted of assaults on 12 female passengers, although the police say he had more than 100 victims.
item.description: The High Court told a parole board to reconsider the case of a London cabdriver who assaulted female passengers, and it called for an end to secrecy rules.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD PÉREZ-PEÑA

item.title: Kim’s Secret Trip to Beijing
item.description: The state news media in China and North Korea confirmed that Kim Jong-un, the North Korean leader, was in the mysterious train that pulled into Beijing on Monday. It was his first official visit abroad since he took office.

item.title: New Arrest in $20 Million Heist, Britain’s Biggest Burglary
item.media:description: The entrance to Hatton Garden Safe Deposit Ltd. in London, where millions of dollars’ worth of jewels, gold, precious stones and cash were stolen in 2015.
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.description: The suspect, 57, was detained in north London in a 2015 burglary carried out by a gang of graying thieves in London’s jewelry district.
item.dc:creator: CEYLAN YEGINSU

item.title: Is Your Waiter Rude, or Merely French? A Debate Is Revived
item.media:description: “The line that ‘I am French so I am rude,’ well, that is not a defense,” said Edith Boncompain, of the French Institute Alliance Française in New York, after a fired waiter in Canada made headlines with such a claim.
item.description: A wrongful termination case in Canada has revived an old cultural stereotype.
item.dc:creator: LAURA M. HOLSON

item.title: Book Listing Hitler as a ‘Great Leader’ Is Removed from Publisher’s Website
item.media:description: This description of the book titled “Leaders,” but listed on the Pegasus website as “Great Leaders,” is no longer available on the publisher’s online store.
item.description: An Indian publishing group came under fire for including the Nazi leader in a book about 11 people who “devoted their lives for the betterment of their country and people.”
item.dc:creator: KAI SCHULTZ

item.title: When Xi Met Kim: How China and North Korea Depicted It
item.media:description: This image of Mr. Xi appearing to offer a toast to Mr. Kim appeared in North Korea’s state media, but not China’s.
item.description: The meeting in Beijing between President Xi Jinping of China and North Korea’s leader Kim Jong-un provided propaganda opportunities on both sides.
item.dc:creator: JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ

item.title: El Al Sues Israel After Air India Flies Through Saudi Airspace
item.media:description: Israel’s national airline, El Al, is required to take a circuitous route to India that avoids the entire Arabian Peninsula.
item.description: Air India became the first commercial airline permitted to fly over Saudi Arabia en route to and from Israel. Claiming discrimination, El Al is suing.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Myanmar Picks a New President, but He’ll Still Be No. 2
item.media:description: Myanmar’s Parliament chose U Win Myint to be the country’s new president, a mostly ceremonial post.
item.description: Chosen by Parliament, U Win Myint is largely expected to do the bidding of Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, who is not allowed to hold the presidency herself.
item.dc:creator: SAW NANG and RICHARD C. PADDOCK

item.title: China Moves to Sideline Underground Bishop, His Colleagues Say
item.media:description: A Palm Sunday Mass at an underground church near Shijiazhuang, China, last year. The Roman Catholic Church in China is divided between churches loyal to Rome and those approved by Beijing.
item.description: Guo Xijin was taken to the city of Xiamen after being briefly detained, and members of his staff said he was expected to resume his forced vacation later this week.
item.dc:creator: IAN JOHNSON

item.title: Australia Diary: Welcome to the Neighborhood
item.media:description: A multicultural group of friends gather to bless a new home.
item.description: After enduring the struggle to buy a home, a multicultural crowd of friends gathers for a Hindu celebration.
item.dc:creator: DIANA OLIVA CAVE

item.title: Saudi Arabia Almost Had a Fashion Week
item.media:description: Looks by the Saudi designer Arwa al-Banawi are shown at Fashion Forward 2017 in Dubai.
item.description: Winds of change may be blowing through the desert kingdom, but a sudden postponement of its first fashion week suggests bumps in the road.
item.dc:creator: ELIZABETH PATON

item.title: Kim Jong-un Met With Xi Jinping in Secret Beijing Visit
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping of China, fourth from left, and the North Korean leader Kim Jong-un, second from right, during a meeting at the Great Hall of the People in Beijing.
item.description: The meeting, Mr. Kim’s first with another head of state, added a new layer of complexity to the global diplomacy around North Korea’s nuclear program.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN LEE MYERS and JANE PERLEZ

item.title: ‘Perfect Sense of Control’: Tributes Flow to French Officer in Terror Attack
item.media:description: A memorial service in Trèbes, France, where a gunman’s attack ended at a supermarket.
item.description: There was terror in the supermarket aisles as a gunman threatened customers, but a calm gendarme helped to save many lives.
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: For as Little as $3 a Vote, Egyptians Trudge to Election Stations
item.media:description: A polling station in Cairo festooned with posters of President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi, who faces no serious opposition in this week’s election.
item.description: With no real challenger in this week’s election, President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi is cajoling, coercing and paying voters to ensure a credible turnout.
item.dc:creator: DECLAN WALSH and NOUR YOUSSEF
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )

item.title: Cambridge Analytica Whistle-Blower Contends Data-Mining Swung Brexit Vote
item.description: Christopher Wylie, who testified to British lawmakers, has become a red-haired, nose-ringed matinee idol in some technology quarters.
item.dc:creator: ELLEN BARRY

item.title: U.N. Renews Push to Solve Its Biggest Mystery: Hammarskjold’s Death
item.media:description: Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold in 1953.
item.description: A judge is looking into whether the 1961 death of Dag Hammarskjold, the United Nations secretary general, was caused by “an external attack.”
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Citizenship, Louisiana, North Korea: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: KAREN ZRAICK and DAVID SCULL

item.title: H&M, a Fashion Giant, Has a Problem: $4.3 Billion in Unsold Clothes
item.media:description: The fashion retailer H&M reported poor earnings on Tuesday, and is sitting on a huge pile of unsold clothes.
item.description: The company outlined the inventory buildup in its latest quarterly report, prompting questions of whether it can adapt to fierce competition and changing consumer tastes.
item.dc:creator: ELIZABETH PATON

item.title: Why the Snow in Parts of Europe Was Orange
item.media:description: Orange snow at the Rosa Khutor ski resort outside Sochi, Russia, on Thursday. Meteorologists say that snow from Siberia mixed with dust blown from the Sahara desert to create the colored snow.
item.description: A mixture of weather phenomena picked up North African dust and carried it far from its source.
item.dc:creator: NIRAJ CHOKSHI and DANIEL VICTOR

item.title: Saudi Crown Prince, on U.S. Visit, Urges Tough Line on Iran
item.media:description: Secretary of Defense Jim Mattis, left, welcomed Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman of Saudi Arabia at the Pentagon last week.
item.description: In a meeting with The New York Times, Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman said that maintaining the Iran nuclear deal was like “waiting for the bullet to reach your head.”
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD

item.title: A Hitler-Era Abortion Law Haunts Merkel, and Germany
item.media:description: A protest in Berlin last week in support of a Polish women’s national strike against the tightening of abortion law in Poland. Germany is wrestling with its own Nazi-era abortion restrictions.
item.description: Germany is the only country in Europe that forbids doctors to publicly advertise that they perform abortions. Chancellor Angela Merkel pledged change, but her conservatives are balking.
item.dc:creator: MELISSA EDDY

item.title: Singapore Journal: Cosmetic Surgery for a Pet Fish? In Asia, This One Is King of the Tank
item.media:description: The Asian arowana, known as the “dragon fish” in Chinese, is one of the world’s most expensive aquarium fish.
item.media:credit: Ore Huiying for The New York Times
item.description: Known as the “dragon fish” in Chinese, the Asian arowana is one of the world’s most expensive aquarium fish and a popular luxury item, especially in China.
item.dc:creator: AMY QIN
item.category: Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species

item.title: Arrest of Catalan Leader Tests Spain, Separatists and E.U.
item.media:description: Police officers in riot gear stopped protesters reaching the Spanish central government offices in Barcelona on Sunday after Catalonia’s former president was arrested by the German police.
item.description: The case of Carles Puigdemont could be a trial for Spain’s treatment of Catalan secession as a law enforcement matter, and for European cohesion.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER
